thread.title: Do Cowboys' offensive problems go beyond injuries to Tony Romo, Dez Bryant?
thread.title_full: Do Cowboys' offensive problems go beyond injuries to Tony Romo, Dez Bryant? | Dallas Morning News

author: Rainer Sabin
title: Do Cowboys' offensive problems go beyond injuries to Tony Romo, Dez Bryant?
text:
With the Cowboys in a reduced state because of injuries, no one would argue that Scott Linehan's job is harder than it's ever been since he joined Dallas' staff before the 2014 campaign.
The offensive coordinator has his hands tied with quarterback Tony Romo and star receiver Dez Bryant sidelined for an extended period of time.
Since both players went down, the Cowboys have struggled to score, averaging 18.5 points per game - the 28 th -highest average in the NFL.
But do the absences of Romo and Bryant provide the only reason for the Dallas' offensive malaise or are there deeper issues at play that could still bog down the Cowboys when both players return?
It's hard to say. The consensus opinion is the offensive line has underperformed. Dallas' average gain per carry is ranked 15 th in the NFL and FootballOutsiders.com, with its advanced metrics, says the Cowboys are in the bottom half in the NFL in pass protection. But is that because former offensive line coach Bill Callahan is no longer there, the running back-by-committee setup hasn't worked according to plan or because defenses are stacking the box with the threats of Bryant and Romo removed?
That's not clear either.
Many would claim the Cowboys' ground attack is weaker this year. Dallas has the 18 th -highest game average for rushing yards. But can that be attributed to DeMarco Murray's exit, the offensive line playing erratically or the quality of running backs used by the Cowboys in their rotation they continue to modify?
It's difficult to draw a definitive conclusion.
There are some who say the Cowboys' passing game has been betrayed by Linehan's lack of creativity and aggressiveness. Dallas has produced the fewest completions of 20 or more yards in the NFL. But is the lack of an explosive element in the Cowboys' offense the result of a void left by Bryant not being filled, shoddy quarterback play in wake of Romo's broken collarbone, or pass protection breakdowns forcing checkdowns underneath the coverage?
That's also not easy to answer.
When there are problems like the ones the Cowboys are experiencing, the knee-jerk reaction is to do something radically different. Yet it's impossible to determine if the Cowboys' offense is fundamentally flawed or if it's just hindered at the moment without its two top talents -- Romo and Bryant. The running game may really be bankrupt and the offensive line depreciated. No one will know for sure until Romo and Bryant get back in the mix.
With so many variables introduced by the departure of Murray and the injuries to Romo and Bryant, all we know is what we don't know. And that is a lot.
